G.L. c. 214.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 214, G.L. c. 186 and the general jurisdiction of the District Court over landlord-tenant disputes.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 214, G.L. c. 186 and the general jurisdiction of the District Court over landlord-tenant disputes.

M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords have a duty to provide and maintain premises that are fit for habitation and free from conditions that materially interfere with the use and enjoyment of the dwelling. See M.G.L. c. 186 (landlord/tenant statutes); M.G.L. c. 111 (public health statutes); 105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation (State Sanitary Code), including provisions governing ventilation, sanitation, and the obligation to prevent conditions hazardous to health.

M.G.L. c. 111.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords have a duty to provide and maintain premises that are fit for habitation and free from conditions that materially interfere with the use and enjoyment of the dwelling. See M.G.L. c. 186 (landlord/tenant statutes); M.G.L. c. 111 (public health statutes); 105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation (State Sanitary Code), including provisions governing ventilation, sanitation, and the obligation to prevent conditions hazardous to health.

105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fi.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation (State Sanitary Code)
105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fi.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords have a duty to provide and maintain premises that are fit for habitation and free from conditions that materially interfere with the use and enjoyment of the dwelling. See M.G.L. c. 186 (landlord/tenant statutes); M.G.L. c. 111 (public health statutes); 105 CMR 410.000, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation (State Sanitary Code), including provisions governing ventilation, sanitation, and the obligation to prevent conditions hazardous to health.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and applicable provisions of M.G.L. c. 111 require landlords to maintain dwellings in a sanitary, safe condition and to provide adequate ventilation and control of moisture to prevent growth of fungi and mold and conditions dangerous to health.

105 CMR 410.100 et seq..proposition: See 105 CMR 410.100 et seq.; M.G.L. c. 111, §§127A, 127I, 127L (public health enforcement generally).

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127A, 127I, 1.proposition: See 105 CMR 410.100 et seq.; M.G.L. c. 111, §§127A, 127I, 127L (public health enforcement generally).

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: The covenant guarantees that a tenant shall have peaceful and lawful possession and enjoyment of the premises without substantial interference by the landlord or conditions that substantially impair habitability or enjoyment.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: The covenant guarantees that a tenant shall have peaceful and lawful possession and enjoyment of the premises without substantial interference by the landlord or conditions that substantially impair habitability or enjoyment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on recognizing and defining an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and the tenant’s remedies for its breach. It speaks in terms of the landlord’s duty to provide premises that are safe, clean, and fit for human habitation, and the tenant’s ability to withhold rent or seek damages when conditions substantially affect health or safety. It does not frame this duty as a ‘covenant’ guaranteeing peaceful and lawful possession or freedom from substantial interference in the broader sense encompassed by the claimed proposition, but rather as a specific warranty of habitability linked to essential facilities and health/safety impacts.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. In determining whether there has been a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, courts should inquire whether the claimed defect has an impact on the safety or health of the tenant.”

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.proposition: The covenant guarantees that a tenant shall have peaceful and lawful possession and enjoyment of the premises without substantial interference by the landlord or conditions that substantially impair habitability or enjoyment.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the landlord’s implied warranty/covenant in residential leases as an obligation to maintain the premises in a habitable condition and to preserve the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment, and it roots this in the evolution of the covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction doctrine. It states that the covenant protects the tenant’s ‘beneficial enjoyment’ and that uninhabitable conditions which materially impair basic living requirements justify withholding rent and are directly relevant to possession, thus encompassing peaceful and lawful possession without substantial interference from the landlord or uninhabitable conditions.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, of course, if the trial court finds that the landlord has not breached the warranty of habitability, it should immediately enter judgment in favor of the landlord. … Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. This implied warranty of habitability does not require that a landlord ensure that leased premises are in perfect, aesthetically pleasing condition, but it does mean that ‘bare living requirements’ must be maintained. In most cases substantial compliance with those applicable building and housing code standards which materially affect health and safety will suffice….”}

Flores v. Williamsburg?.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remediate mold and to maintain adequate ventilation that results in persistent mold growth, health risks, property damage and loss of use constitutes a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and use of the premises and is actionable.

Ames v. King?.proposition: Ames v. King?, analogous Massachusetts authority recognizing landlord duties regarding habitability and tenant remedies (see Massachusetts landlord-tenant precedent addressing quiet enjoyment and habitability principles).
